content.description: Park at Little Eiger.  Below the road is a couple of large boulders. Truly Scrumptious is riverside on the right boulder as you face the road.
content.protection: This was done without a pad, but one would be nice.

content.description: Start low by the river, just left of the yellow cannabis tree tagging. Continue straight up the arete to a long, hard cross move after the good rail (harder if you're shorter). Continue straight up for the topout, and DON'T GET WET!!!
content.protection: Pads, although a fall at the crux will put you in the river (but it's shallow... sometimes).
content.location: Park at the pullout just after the green bridge. Walk back toward the bridge on the opposite side of the road from the eiger. Scramble down and left to see a beautiful overhanging face above a boulder and the river.

content.description: Start sitting matched with both of your hands in the diagonal crimp rail near the right side of the boulder, then move right out to the slopey crack rail feature, and follow it to the top.
content.location:
It is to the right of

Butterfly Effect

.

content.description: This is a fun problem that must be done in the winter when there is ice at the bottom of the boulder, otherwise there's a two feet of water at the base. Start with your left hand low on a sidepull and your right hand in a good finger slot at about eye level. Move up left through some mono-crimps and a long move left to a sloper followed by a long right to a sloper and straight up to top out.
content.location: It is located on the boulder next to the 'Smoke and Fire' Boulder, the one that's in the river....

content.description: Sit start down above a rock and driftwood pile in a little cave with your left hand on a juggy hold in the crack between the boulders, and your right on a sloping pinch to the left of the big rail.  Move up and right to the two rounded crimps, then left to a bad pinch and bump to a sharp finger slot.  Then, set up to throw your right hand up to the jug beneath the grassy area on top, keep moving right on jugs to the highest point on the boulder, then mantle over.
content.protection: Pads, and watch out for the boulders behind you; however, falling off the harder moves gives way to decent landings.
content.location:
It is located on the same boulder as '

Smoke on the Water

' but is just to the left of the face tagging.

content.description:
Start as for "

Fire In The Sky

."  Once the small crimps on the face above are gained move right into a slopy gaston with your right.  Next pull  like mad into a left handed (moon shaped) side-pull/crimp.  Working with terrible foot placements, pop out right to a crappy side pull then quickly move your right hand again to gain a better pinch.  Setup the feet and blast up with either your right or your left (move still not done!!) to snag a good but small crimp!!!  Then desperately toss onto the jugs above and climb them to the top-out!!!

This will be a desperate line for sure!!  Who ever gets the F.A. just let me know and I will post the name you have chosen if you decided to change the project reference name.  Happy hunting!!
content.protection: Pads and spotters.  During the creeks run-off months it is suggested to anchor your pads to the base of the line and have a great spotter or you could get wet, hurt or hurt and wet!!!
content.location: This is located at the roadside boulders of "The Little Eiger." The problem is on the "Fire In The Sky Boulder" which is the eastern most block before the bridge.

content.description: This small boulder has an interesting short problem.  It starts left in a slopey corner and right on an undercling, bump to the slopey rail, and pull the lip to make an awkward mantle to topout.
content.location: This is just upstream about 30 feet from the Animal Boulder.

content.description:
From two, fairly high, opposing sidepulls climb the face and shallow corner about 3 feet right of "

Smoke On The Water

." There is a much harder lower start which begins with the (R) on a rounded polished side-pull sloper and the (L) on a terrible undercling. This version is perhaps more like V9'ish?

The line is quite dirty but with time it should clean up nicely. It is a good warm-up for the "Fire In The Sky Boulder."
content.location:
Located creek side and across the road from the "Little Eiger" on the "Fire In The Sky Boulder" which is just east of the "Animal Boulder," the problem climbs the face and shallow corner about 3 feet right of "

Smoke On The Water

."

content.description:
Somehow this mega-classic was overlooked for many years, despite being right across the river from Animal.

Begin on the left side of the beautiful overhang, sitting on a perfect jug. Move up and right across the face via long moves between brilliant, incut crimps and rails to a finishing dyno/deadpoint to a positive sidepull. Top out up and right on easier terrain.

I have no doubt that this will become the most popular V12/13 in CCC; the holds are small yet incut, crispy but comfy, and the landing is very good (thanks to some log work). Originally graded V14 and dubbed “the Mirror Reality of Clear Creek,” numerous quick repeats dropped the grade to V13, and now it’s about 50/50 between V12 and V13, but it’s still a great line on RMNP-esque granite.
content.protection: 2-3 pads. It is pretty safe to do solo.
content.location: This is across the river from Animal, below Red Slab. In the winter, an ice bridge may be present, and in the warmer months, the approach is still a fairly chill walk from the bridge. The line climbs through crimps on the obvious overhang. Aside from a few other miscellaneous moderates, there is nothing else on the boulder.

content.description: Start underneath the boulder by the river on a sloper and an undercling. Throw around the roof and get the slick crimpy rail, match, then go up left to a crimpy pinch hold. Then move up right with a heelhook to a slopey pocket, and match above. Top out up and right.
content.location: It is on the west side of the boulder right next to the pulloff that is underneath The Little Eiger.
This is on a small boulder below Little Eiger that has "Abney 74" written on it.
